noun.description: A part-song for several voices, especially one of the Renaissance period, typically arranged in elaborate counterpoint and without instrumental accompaniment. Originally used of a genre of 14th-century Italian songs, the term now usually refers to English or Italian songs of the late 16th and early 17th c., in a free style strongly influenced by the text.

origin: From Italian madrigale (from medieval Latin carmen matricale simple song), from matricalis maternal or primitive, from matrix womb.
